Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: GEM--Hot Flow Anomalies at the Earth's Bow Shock and Their Geomagnetic Effects
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hot flow anomalies (HFAs) are kinetic phenomena observed near planetary bow shocks that are characterized by heated plasma and flow deflection. The objective of this proposal is to determine the properties of HFAs and their generating mechanisms. The study will systematically survey two types of HFAs. They are traditional HFAs which are associated with interplanetary magnetic field discontinuities and spontaneous HFAs which occur in the absence of magnetic field discontinuities. This study will use a large data base from the Cluster and THEMIS satellites coupled with analytic theory and hybrid simulations.

The Principal Investigator (PI) is a young woman assistant professor and this grant will support a female graduate student. The results of this study will be used in the PI's classes. She will make the data base available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hot flow anomalies (HFAs) are phenomena observed near planetary bow shocks that are marked by greatly heated solar wind plasmas and substantial flow deflection (and sometimes even flows backward toward the Sun). HFAs are universal phenomena. HFAs have been observed at the bow shock of the Earth, Mars, Saturn, Venus, and Mercury. HFAs may have a substantial impact on the solar wind-magnetosphere-ionosphere interaction because they drive magnetopause boundary waves, transmit compressional waves into the magnetosphere that can excite resonant ultralow frequency waves and scatter charged particles to precipitate into the ionosphere, generate field-aligned currents in the magnetosphere that drive magnetic impulse events in the high-latitude ionosphere, and trigger transient auroral brightening. The objective of this project is to determine the characteristics of HFAs, understand their generation mechanisms, and determine their impact on the magnetosphere and ionosphere.

The first major finding of this project concerns the HFA formation conditions. HFAs are thought to result from the interaction between interplanetary discontinuities and Earth's bow shock. Since there are much more interplanetary discontinuities than HFAs, the question is what kind of discontinuities is more efficient to generate HFAs. We found that magnetic field on at least one side of the interplanetary discontinuities has to be connected to the bow shock in order to form HFAs. Discontinuities with large shear angles are more efficient to form HFAs. Current sheets with thickness from 1000 km to about 3162 km are more efficient to form HFAs. HFAs are more likely to form when the reflected flow from the bow shock is along the discontinuity. An original upstream discontinuity in the vicinity of an HFA and/or at least one side of the HFA with the convective electric field pointing toward the discontinuity may help an HFA growing, but it is not a necessary condition to generate an HFA. The second major finding of this project concerns the characteristics of HFAs at different evolution stages (young or mature). We found that both ion and electron spectra can be used to classify young and mature HFAs. Classifications according to ion and electron spectra are not absolutely consistent, which might be due to different heating mechanisms for ions and electrons. Statistical analysis shows that variations of plasma parameters and the magnetic field inside mature HFAs are more dramatic than those inside young HFAs, except for temperature, and the duration of mature HFAs is longer than that of young HFAs. The third major finding is that HFA can affect the Earth’s magnetosphere and ionosphere significantly. We found that the magnetopause bulged out by at least 4 Earth radii (RE) due to the passage of an HFA. Observations of the IMAGE magnetometer network at 9 magnetic local time (MLT) show clear response to this extreme HFA. The ionospheric equivalent currents show a strong eastward component at 76-79 degree latitude. Cluster located in the dawnside magnetotail also observed a clear response to this extreme HFA.

HFAs are universal phenomena that are associated with shock waves in plasmas that are found in many environments, from the solar atmosphere to distant galaxies. Therefore the findings from this project have broad scientific impact. Results from this proposal provide a better understanding of kinetic processes in a collisionless plasma. Results obtained by this project can be applied to any shock.

A total of 5 papers have been published in peer-reviewed journals. In addition, 10 presentations (1 invited) were given at scientific conferences. The PI and Co-I of this project (and 2 co-Chairs) lead a NSF GEM focus group titled "Transient Phenomena at the Magnetopause and Bow Shock and Their Ground Signatures”. A table and a short description of some transient foreshock phenomena, together with a list of HFA and Foreshock Bubble events with summary plots has been posted on the GEM wiki page, which is accessible to the community. 

This project promotes teaching, training and learning by engaging a graduate student and an undergraduate student in the work. This project also contributes to curriculum development in plasma physics and magnetospheric physics.
